CLUE: International radio signal of distress at sea
OUTPUT: ["It was chosen because it's composed of three dots (or short signals), followed by three dashes and then three more dots when transmitted in Morse code; this sequence is easy to recognize and remember as a distress signal.", 'Before its widespread adoption, there were many different signals for indicating distress on ships and by ship-to-shore radio stations', 'Its simplicity made it quick to transmit and easy to understand despite language barriers or stressful situations.', 'It did not need any gaps between the characters, which could reduce transmission time during critical moments.', 'The repetition of three signals is a pattern that can be recognized easily even in noisy conditions.', 'This code was distinct from other codes used at the time and would stand out as an urgent call for help.', 'It was agreed upon by international agreement, lending it credibility and authority across different countries and languages.', 'However, with advancements in technology, newer systems like the Global Maritime Distress Safety System (GMDSS) have taken over for modern communications']
